title:
PSYC BC1101 STATISTICS  

Download PDF version of syllabus
text:
Course Overview
This course, required for the psychology major, provides an introduction to statistical methods commonly used in psychological research. Topics include measures of central tendency and variability, probability and sampling, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing, t-test and analysis of variance, correlation and regression. In addition to learning the conceptual and mathematical underpinnings of these techniques, you will learn to calculate and interpret statistics with reference to real-world contexts and research questions typical in psychological research. The course includes recitation meetings that provide instruction in the analysis of psychological data using the R statistical software package commonly used by behavioral science researchers.
The course is designed to fulfill these goals:

Understand what statistics are, and why and when they are needed
Translate observations about the world into statistical statements and questions
Learn how statistical methods are used to test psychological hypotheses
Use statistical software (R) to describe, visualize, analyze, and report data

title: BC1101
text:
Math

Statistics requires basic math skills
E.g. order of operations

Parentheses
Exponents (like squaring/square root)
Multiplication & division
Summation
Addition & subtraction

title: BC1101
text:
Math

Summation

Symbol \(\Sigma\) (Greek letter Sigma) means add up
Summation is done after operations in parentheses, squaring, and multiplication or division, but before other addition or subtraction
E.g… \(X = [2, 4, 7]\)


\[\Sigma X = ? \\
\Sigma X + 1 = ? \\
\Sigma(X + 1) = ?\]

title: BC1101
text:
Math

Algebra

Rearranging equations
E.g.


\[\begin{align}12 &= 7 + X \\ X &= ? \end{align}\]

Good for your career

“In the United States today half of all children (35.6 million) live in a household where a parent or other adult uses tobacco, drinks heavily or uses illicit drugs”1]

title: BC1101
text:
Constructs & operational definitions

Construct: Extroversion
Operational definition: Big 5 questions



Construct: Intelligence
Operational definition: IQ test




Construct: Height
Operational definition: How far the top of your head is from the floor according to a tape measure

title: BC1101
text:
Measuring things

Operationalizing variables

Usually more than one way we could go about measuring & recording data
Result in different types of data, and potentially different applicable analyses
How to decide on operational definition?

Aspects to consider:

Type of variable (discrete / continuous)
Scale of measurement (nominal / ordinal / interval / ratio)

title: BC1101
text:
Types of variable



Discrete

Something we count as whole numbers
Made up of separate, indivisible categories
No values exist between neighboring categories

Examples:

Number of children/cats/TVs
Positive cases
Hospital admissions




Continuous

Something we can measure with decimals
Has infinite number of possible values
Every interval is divisible into infinite number of parts

Examples

Height
Time
Temperature

title: BC1101
text:
Scales of measurement




 
  
    Scale 
    Characteristics 
    Examples 
  
 

  
    Nominal 
    Named categories
                                      No quantitative distinctions 
    GenderEye colorExperimental condition 
  
  
    Ordinal 
    Ordered categories
                                      Indicates direction, but not size of difference 
    RankClothing sizesOlympic medals 
  
  
    Interval 
    Ordered categories
                                      Equal intervals between categories
                                      Arbitrary or absent zero point 
    Temperature (Celcius/Fahrenheit)Golf scores 
  
  
    Ratio 
    Ordered categories
                                      Equal interval between categories
                                      Absolute zero point 
    Temperature (Kelvin)
                               Number of correct answers
                               Response time

title: BC1101
text:
Measuring things
Likert scales

E.g. “What is your current level of happiness?”



A lot less than usual
A little less than usual
About average
A little more than usual
A lot more than usual

title: BC1101
text:
Statistics

A bunch of numbers looking for an argument. 1


Mathematical procedures used to collect, organize, summarize & interpret information

Provide standardized evaluation procedures
Tell us about patterns of interest in data

Etymology

Statistics comes from status, meaning state
The state of the state
Census, birth/death rate, incomes, unemployment etc


Jones, 2011

title: BC1101
text:
Frequency

How often does something occur?

E.g. opinion polling (FiveThirtyEight)

title: BC1101
text:
Frequency

A frequency distribution…

Organizes and displays data
Conveys how scores are distributed
Can be either a table or a graph

Shows:

Categories that make up the scale
Frequency, or number of observations, in each category
And/or proportion/percentage/cumulative percent of scores in each category

title: BC1101
text:
Grouped frequency table

What’s the range of scores?
How can you turn that into about 10 groups? (using a simple number, e.g. 2, 5, 10…)
What should we make the bottom score of each interval? (so that the bottom is a multiple of width, i.e, start at 10, not 11)
List intervals in \(X\) column, frequencies in \(f\) column
(optional) Create columns for proportion, percent, cumulative percent

title: BC1101
text:
Grouped frequency table



Grouped frequency table

Bins all same width
Width is a simple number (2)
Bottom score is multiple of width (i.e, divisible by 2)
Produces good number of bins







 
  
    \(X\) 
    \(f\) 
  
 

  
    40-41 
    1 
  
  
    42-43 
    1 
  
  
    44-45 
    2 
  
  
    46-47 
    0 
  
  
    48-49 
    1 
  
  
    50-51 
    3 
  
  
    52-53 
    6 
  
  
    54-55 
    7 
  
  
    56-57 
    9 
  
  
    58-59 
    10

title: BC1101
text:
Frequency graphs



Histogram, frequency polygon, bar chart, curve

Appropriate type depends on:

Level of measurement (nominal; ordinal; interval; ratio)
Describing sample or population?
Want to show more than one group?

title: BC1101
text:
Bar graph



For nominal or ordinal data
Categories on \(x\)-axis, frequency on \(y\)-axis
Spaces between adjacent bars indicates separate categories

title: BC1101
text:
Histogram



For interval or ratio data
Scores/bins on \(x\)-axis, frequency on \(y\)-axis
Height corresponds to frequency
Bars centered on category

title: BC1101
text:
Histogram



For interval or ratio data
Scores/bins on \(x\)-axis, frequency on \(y\)-axis
Height corresponds to frequency
Bars centered on category

title: BC1101
text:
Frequency polygon



For interval or ratio data
Scores/bins on \(x\)-axis, frequency on \(y\)-axis
Height corresponds to frequency
Bars centered on category

title: BC1101
text:
Smooth curves



Used for population distributions

When population is large, scores for each individual are usually not known
Smooth curve indicates exact scores were not used
Convey relative frequency

title: BC1101
text:
Learning checks



Use the frequency table to the right to determine how many participants were in the study.
Which graph (histogram / frequency polygon / bar chart / curve) is appropriate for showing:

Marital status (single/married/divorced)
Letter grades (A+, A, A-, B+, etc)
Time spent watching Netflix
